channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Why 'Marty Supreme' marks a new chapter for Josh Safdie
item.description: Josh Safdie discusses his upcoming film 'Marty Supreme', set for release on December 25.
item.content:encoded: Josh Safdie discusses his upcoming film 'Marty Supreme', set for release on December 25.
item.dc:creator: Marc Rivers

item.title: The quiet pull of introspective songs as temperatures fall
item.description: When temperatures drop, why do many listeners find themselves gravitating toward more introspective, emotionally resonant songs?
item.content:encoded: When temperatures drop, why do many listeners find themselves gravitating toward more introspective, emotionally resonant songs?
item.dc:creator: Miles Parks

item.title: Homeowners stall Connecticut's push for more housing
item.description: Connecticut's governor seeks compromise between housing needs and homeowner opposition.
item.content:encoded: Connecticut's governor seeks compromise between housing needs and homeowner opposition.
item.dc:creator: Molly Ingram

item.title: What lawmakers advanced, and stalled, on health care this week
item.description: Julie Rovner, chief Washington correspondent for KFF Health News, on Congress's healthcare stalemate and what it means for ACA marketplace shoppers.
item.content:encoded: Julie Rovner, chief Washington correspondent for KFF Health News, on Congress's healthcare stalemate and what it means for ACA marketplace shoppers.
item.dc:creator: Julie Rovner

item.title: Covering vaccines in an age of distrust
item.description: NPR's Rob Stein explains why covering vaccines is no longer routine science journalism, but a political battleground.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Rob Stein explains why covering vaccines is no longer routine science journalism, but a political battleground.
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: University of Alabama suspends student magazines amid DEI crackdown
item.description: Kendal Wright, editor in chief of the University of Alabama's Nineteen Fifty-Six magazine, reacts to the suspension of two student publications amid a federal crackdown on campus DEI policies.
item.content:encoded: Kendal Wright, editor in chief of the University of Alabama's Nineteen Fifty-Six magazine, reacts to the suspension of two student publications amid a federal crackdown on campus DEI policies.
item.dc:creator: Miles Parks

item.title: How immigration myths from the past still shape today's debates
item.description: Professor Nancy Foner on the myths regarding early 20th century immigration to the U.S. and the claims of Vice President Vance on their assimilation.
item.content:encoded: Professor Nancy Foner on the myths regarding early 20th century immigration to the U.S. and the claims of Vice President Vance on their assimilation.
item.dc:creator: Ahmad Damen

item.title: Inside Turning Point USA's uneasy moment after Charlie Kirk
item.description: Turning Point USA has kicked off its first national conference since the death of Charlie Kirk. The event is typically a rallying point for conservatives, but divides inside MAGA have been on display.
item.content:encoded: Turning Point USA has kicked off its first national conference since the death of Charlie Kirk. The event is typically a rallying point for conservatives, but divides inside MAGA have been on display.
item.dc:creator: Elena Moore

item.title: Available to download Friday, some Epstein files no longer there Saturday afternoon
item.description: An NPR analysis of the Epstein files shows some documents, originally available on Friday, are no longer on the Department of Justice's "Epstein Library" website as the DOJ releases more files.
item.content:encoded:
An NPR analysis of the Epstein files shows some documents, originally available on Friday, are no longer on the Department of Justice's "Epstein Library" website as the DOJ releases more files.

(Image credit: Andrew Harnik)
item.dc:creator: Casey Morell

item.title: Russian luge athletes compete alongside Ukrainians in Lake Placid, N.Y.
item.description: Russian athletes trying to qualify for the Winter Olympics are in Lake Placid, sharing the luge track with counterparts from Ukraine. It's complicated, like Russians' path to compete in Milan.
item.content:encoded: Russian athletes trying to qualify for the Winter Olympics are in Lake Placid, sharing the luge track with counterparts from Ukraine. It's complicated, like Russians' path to compete in Milan.
item.dc:creator: Emily Russell
